newsitem.title: FRANCE: France rejects idea of U.S. mediation in Algeria.
newsitem.headline: France rejects idea of U.S. mediation in Algeria.

text.p: France dismissed on Friday the notion of United States mediation in Algeria's civil violence, saying Algerians must resolve their own problems.
"Algerian matters must be resolved by the Algerians themselves," a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

He had been asked about a proposal by Algeria's main secular opposition leader, Hocine Ait Ahmed, that U.S. President Bill Clinton should appoint a special envoy to help to end the violence racking Algeria.
Moslem radicals have been fighting a guerrilla war since early 1992 when the authorities cancelled a general election that Islamists were poised to win. About 60,000 people have been killed.

Washington sidestepped comment on Ahmed's proposal, made in Rome on Thursday. "The United States has not been asked by the government of Algeria to play the kind of role that this individual has suggested," State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said.
"We have to respect the wishes of the government of Algeria, obviously, in a case like this," he told a news briefing.
Burns said the United States "rejects the actions of the terrorists who are killing innocent Algerians and killing innocent foreigners." He declined further comment.
